results.headline: A World Teaches and Tugs
results.summary_short: “A Letter to Momo” covers a range of emotions as it tells the story of a young girl whose father was lost at sea.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Letter to Momo

results.headline: A Power Broker’s World Comes Tumbling Down
results.summary_short: Wallace Shawn turns the title character of Ibsen’s imperious “Master Builder” into a megalomaniacal little creep facing his death and his past.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Master Builder

results.headline: For a Struggling Actor, New Roles
results.summary_short: “Wish I Was Here” looks at a middle-class family forced to change its ways by the costly illness of its patriarch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wish I Was Here

results.headline: A Long and Winding History of Gaming
results.summary_short: In “Video Games: The Movie,” dozens of celebrities and game developers, among others, explore the history and impact of video games on society.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Video Games: The Movie

results.headline: Pay Your Taxes, Kill the Neighbors
results.summary_short: In “The Purge: Anarchy,” Americans are again asked to spend a night running amok and killing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Purge: Anarchy

results.headline: Oops! Pushed the Wrong Button
results.summary_short: Jason Segel and Cameron Diaz star as a married couple who scramble to keep their homemade erotic video private in “Sex Tape.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex Tape

results.headline: Fire Flight
results.summary_short: In “Planes: Fire & Rescue” a crop-dusting plane embarks on a second career as a firefighter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planes: Fire and Rescue

results.headline: They’re Out to Get Him, Whoever They Are
results.summary_short: “Persecuted” finds a television evangelist holding out against a vaguely defined piece of legislation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Persecuted

results.headline: As Boy Woos Girl, Whimsy Is in the Picture
results.summary_short: In “Mood Indigo,” Audrey Tautou and Romain Duris star in a whimsical love story adapted from the French novel “L’Écume des Jours.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mood Indigo

results.headline: Color Wars Tinged by Surreal Hysteria
results.summary_short: In “K Missing Kings,” based on a Japanese anime series, clansmen bearing the colors of their king do battle with similar groups of rivals.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of K Missing Kings

results.headline: Making the Spiritually Skeptical Believe, and the Blind Worms See
results.summary_short: Mike Cahill’s “I Origins” is a sci-fi romance about two genetic researchers and a mysterious woman who sees things more spiritually than scientifically.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Origins

results.display_title: Double Play: James Benning and Richard Linklater
results.headline: Duet for Directors, in a Conversational Key
results.summary_short: The film directors Richard Linklater and James Benning chat about their shared interests in the documentary “Double Play.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Double Play: James Benning and Richard Linklater

results.headline: Three Fathers Make an Impression
results.summary_short: Marius, his father and the sailmaker who marries the pregnant title character fuel “Fanny,” the middle film of a trilogy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fanny

results.headline: A Family Gathers, and So Does the Dysfunction
results.summary_short: In “Among Ravens,” relatives and their problems gather at a Fourth of July getaway.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Among Ravens

results.headline: At Nursing Homes, Medicine That’s Heard
results.summary_short: Music is used to care for the aging in a documentary by Michael Rossato-Bennett.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alive Inside

results.headline: It’s All Over, but the Dying
results.summary_short: In “Aftermath,” by Peter Engert, a cellar-bound gang of desperate survivors tries to cope after a global nuclear catastrophe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aftermath

results.headline: Long on Travel, but Short on Satisfaction
results.summary_short: In “A Five Star Life,” a hotel critic’s job sends her around the world, and she ends up questioning her decisions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Five Star Life

results.headline: A Smitten Boy Senses an Opening and Seizes It
results.summary_short: In “The Empty Hours,” a 17-year-old looking after his uncle’s hotel connects with a woman who is a regular guest.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Empty Hours

results.display_title: Dawn of the Planet of the Apes
results.headline: Neighbors Who Need Good Fences
results.summary_short: In “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” civilized apes and devastated humans debate what to do about each other.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes

results.headline: From Baby Fat to Stubble: Growing Up in Real Time
results.summary_short: Richard Linklater’s tender and profound film, which follows a boy and his family over a dozen years in real time, is a meticulously textured work set to the rhythm of life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boyhood
